text:
Here‚Äôs 5 mistakes I made in my first year as a data analyst (and how I‚Äôve learned from them):

1Ô∏è‚É£ Jumping straight into writing SQL or code.
‚Ü≥ Start by defining the scope of the project: What‚Äôs the goal? What decisions will this analysis inform?

2Ô∏è‚É£ Focusing too much on technology with stakeholders.
‚Ü≥ Talk about the impact of the project over the technical details.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Not validating the results of an analysis.
‚Ü≥ Even if the code runs without errors, I always double-check for issues like duplicates or wrong aggregations.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Neglecting the business context.
‚Ü≥ Meet with stakeholder to understand business goals and how my role fits into the big picture.

5Ô∏è‚É£ Trying to do everything.
‚Ü≥ Prioritize big wins and impactful projects that deliver the most value.

After a year as a data analyst, I‚Äôve been working on thinking like a senior analyst.

A senior role goes beyond completing the tasks, it‚Äôs about collaboration, understanding the business, and making a bigger impact.

Here‚Äôs how I‚Äôve been working on this transition:

Proactivity:
‚Ü≥ Spotting trends, forming hypotheses, and diving into the data to validate or pivot based on the findings.

Adding value:
‚Ü≥ Going beyond the basics in projects. Even simple things like adding my thoughts on an ad hoc request, can make a difference (a tip my mentor shared that‚Äôs been very helpful).

Stakeholder partnership:
‚Ü≥ Building stronger relationships with stakeholders, becoming a subject matter expert and a partner, not just someone who pulls data.

Business acumen:
‚Ü≥ Learning more about my industry by researching competitors and reading product-focused content.

Automation:
‚Ü≥ Automating processes (e.g. my weekly report) to free up time for bigger, more impactful projects.

Junior roles are important and you can make impact there; everyone starts somewhere. But I‚Äôm focusing on reaching the next level in my career.

‚ùìSenior analysts, do you have any advice for people just starting out in their career?

During my data analyst job search, I got stuck at nearly every stage of the hiring process.

Each time I took a step back, analyzed the problem, and worked on a solution.

üõë No interviews
üü¢ I revised my resume: it to specific job titles like data analyst, emphasized focused my transferrable skills, and experimented with different version). I also continued to network.

üõë Stuck at the recruiter call or hiring manager interview:
üü¢ Spent time creating a clear story to explain my career transition and how my transferable skills fit the role.

üõë Told I was a ‚Äúgood candidate‚Äù but I lacked real-world experience
üü¢ I created my own experience by volunteering with a non-profit and using data at part-time marketing role using data.

üõë Struggled in the technical interview
üü¢ I didn‚Äôt just practice SQL problems but also practiced explaining my reasoning and concepts as well.

üõë Didn‚Äôt receive an offer
üü¢ I reminded myself that sometimes, the decision comes down to factors outside my control like team dynamics or other candidates‚Äô experience. What mattered was that I did everything I could.

This wasn‚Äôt a quick fix, it took the time to identify where I was struggling and to address each gap.

P.S. While I job searched from October 2022 to June 2023, I know today‚Äôs market is even tougher. But, taking the time to analyze my own data and focus on what I could control made a big difference.

When I decided to switch careers and become a data analyst, I couldn‚Äôt afford a bootcamp or grad school. So I created my own learning path:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Used the Google Data Analytics Course as a roadmap.
2Ô∏è‚É£ Focused on learning 3 tools: SQL, Tableau, and Python.
3Ô∏è‚É£ Sharpened my skills with an additional course (one for each tool).
4Ô∏è‚É£ Built a personal project for each skill after completing its course.
5Ô∏è‚É£ Shared my projects on LinkedIn to get feedback.

Why did this work for me?
‚úÖ It kept me focused on learning a few tools deeply.
‚úÖ Showcased my knowledge and passion with unique projects.
‚úÖ Helped me practice communication by writing about my work.

Thanks to Jess Ramos, MSBA with her post yesterday that inspired this one.

P.S. I know there‚Äôs a lot more to the job search than just the skills. Tomorrow I‚Äôll share more about what I did.

Me: Writing a thoughtful comment on a post.

LinkedIn: This post is actually a month old.

Me: ...

------

So I‚Äôm sorry if I like or comment on a really old posts üòÖ For some reason my LinkedIn feed keeps showing me posts that are 2+ weeks old.

P.S. Yes, I know you can change to view your feed in ‚Äúmost recent‚Äù in the settings, but this hasn‚Äôt been as much of an issue until recently.

The churn prediction model I built is helping the marketing team win back high-value customers.

Next steps:
‚Ü≥ Test the model with targeted offers.
‚Ü≥ Analyze performance and refine the model.
‚Ü≥ Explore using Google Cloud‚Äôs ML tools for scalability and optimization.

Excited to see how this turns out!

üîó Links to my blog posts about the model in the comments below.

Whenever we add a new feature, before writing any SQL, I make sure I understand how the data flows from our website to our database.

This helps me write queries, especially when I use CASE WHEN statements for filtering specific rows.

For example, if we added a new game, I‚Äôd look at the game data table and focus on two specific columns:
‚óºÔ∏è player_moves - logs each action a player takes (e.g., Move A, Move B, etc.)
‚óºÔ∏èspecial_outcomes - logs only actions that result in special outcomes (e.g., reaching a bonus or triggering a combo).

If I want to count how often players achieve these special outcomes, my CASE WHEN logic filters only rows where special_outcomes is populated. I would write:

COUNT(CASE WHEN special_outcomes = 'Bonus' THEN special_outcomes END) AS number_of_bonuses

I‚Äôm not a data engineer, but having this knowledge helps me get a deeper understanding of the data logic.

If you‚Äôre interested in learning more, subscribe to my newsletter where I‚Äôll be sharing the full query:
https://lnkd.in/gEK8CEt7

How I‚Äôve been applying what I learn from books to my data analyst work.

1Ô∏è‚É£ Read only the relevant chapters (e.g. time series analysis & cohort analysis).

2Ô∏è‚É£ Skim the rest to focus on the most impactful content.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Find new concepts for existing or future projects.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Validate that each technique adds business value:
‚Ü≥ Updating a query with a window function? ‚úÖ It saves processing time ‚Üí reduces query costs ‚Üí saves money.
‚Ü≥ Running another cohort analysis? ‚ùå Not always, especially if the cohort is too small to yield meaningful insights.

I focus on staying intentional and prioritizing impactful projects to ensure my learning drives results.

P.S. The book I‚Äôm currently reading is: SQL for Data Analysis by Cathy Tanimura.

I‚Äôve never had a stakeholder ask about the technical details of an analysis.

They weren't interested in the Python library I used or a new SQL function I implemented, it was all about the impact and results.

Here‚Äôs what I focus on when talking to stakeholders:
‚óºÔ∏è Actively listen to their feedback and concerns.
‚óºÔ∏è Highlight the impact/results, not the methods.
‚óºÔ∏è Understand how they plan to use the data.
‚óºÔ∏è Identify what matters to them and their goals.
‚óºÔ∏è Use clear language and avoid technical terms.

With my team, I can get into the nerdy details. But with stakeholders, it‚Äôs about everything after the analysis: WHAT we can do with the data and HOW it helps us reach business goals.

P.S. There‚Äôs always exceptions, some stakeholders may be interested in the technical side. But in my experience, they usually aren't.

My newest habit as a data analyst: following through on projects.

Before, I‚Äôd submit a project and move on. Now I follow up on:
‚óºÔ∏è How the project was used.
‚óºÔ∏è The impact and results.
‚óºÔ∏è Whether additional analysis or improvements are needed.
‚óºÔ∏è How insights were applied in making decisions.

Why do this? It helps me:
‚óºÔ∏è Build a better understanding of the company and specific departments (e.g. marketing)
‚óºÔ∏è Be proactive, I can spot trends before being asked and work on higher level projects.
‚óºÔ∏è Gain context for future projects.

A few examples:
‚û°Ô∏è A marketing analysis I delivered led to another successful campaign, driving new revenue.
‚û°Ô∏è Finance uses my report to detect fraud earlier, reducing operational costs.

To make sure this done every time, I‚Äôve added this process to my SOP (standard operating procedure) for every project.

I see a lot of books recommended for learning technical skills. But what about the other skills?

I fell into this trap myself yesterday. I shared a list of technical books that helped me learn tools like Python and SQL. But being a good data analyst takes more than just technical knowledge.

It also requires:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Domain knowledge - Understanding your industry
2Ô∏è‚É£ Soft skills - problem solving, communication, etc.

Credit to Drew Mooney for this list in his post today.

‚ùìWhat books would you recommend to improve these skills?

P.S. Storytelling with Data by Cole Nussbaumer Knaflic is already on my list.

Links to Storytelling with Data, Drew‚Äôs original post, and my technical book list from yesterday are in the comments below üëá

Happiness is never about - Job, Degree, Relationships etc.

One day you're going to realise that happiness is about discovering, listening to your heart, having the ability to choose things that please your heart.

Happiness is not just about following the footsteps of people who came before you. It's more about "Being You"

Happiness is about being kinder to yourself.
It is about embracing the person that you're becoming.

It is about enjoying the path, it's not just reaching the destination.

Happiness is about accepting yourself and living with yourself, this happiness is not in the hands of other people.

It is about you.
It was always about you.
It will always be about you.

Started this year with "jo hoga, dekha jaayega"

Ending this year with "Jo hua, nahi dekha Jaa Raha hai"

Time for a change in 2025 üôÇ

India has the highest suicide rate in the world: 12.4 per 100,000 people.

This isn‚Äôt just a statistic‚Äîit‚Äôs a wake-up call. Behind every number is a story, a person, a family.

Mental health in India is still shrouded in stigma. Many are too afraid or ashamed to ask for help. Conversations around mental health are often brushed under the rug, leaving countless individuals to suffer in silence.

But here‚Äôs the truth: seeking help isn‚Äôt a weakness‚Äîit‚Äôs courage in action.

If you‚Äôre reading this and feel overwhelmed, here are three things I want you to remember:

1. It‚Äôs okay to feel broken.

Life isn‚Äôt about always being strong; it‚Äôs about finding the strength to keep going.

2. You‚Äôre not alone.

Reach out to a trusted friend, family member, or even a stranger. People care more than you think.

3. Help is available.

Therapy, helplines, and support groups exist to guide you through tough times.

And for those of us who know someone struggling:
- Listen without judgment.
- Be patient.
- Encourage them to seek professional help.

If we normalize these conversations, we can save lives.

You matter. Your struggles matter. And most importantly, there is a light at the end of the tunnel.

Let‚Äôs make mental health a priority. Together, we can break the stigma.

Did you know your brain has the ability to rewire itself, adapt, and grow‚Äîeven in the face of challenges?

This phenomenon is called neuroplasticity, and it‚Äôs one of the most fascinating discoveries in neuroscience.

Imagine this: You‚Äôre learning a new skill, like coding, playing an instrument, or even managing your emotions better.

Each time you practice, your brain is creating and strengthening new neural pathways. It‚Äôs like building a road in a dense forest‚Äîthe more you walk the path, the clearer and faster it becomes.

Neuroplasticity isn‚Äôt just about learning; it‚Äôs about healing.

The person overcoming anxiety learns to reframe thoughts.

The professional bouncing back after a failure develops resilience.

The individual recovering from trauma builds new patterns of thought and behavior.

Your brain doesn‚Äôt care where you start‚Äîit only cares about where you go from here.

So, whether you‚Äôre:

Struggling to keep up with a demanding career,
Trying to unlearn toxic habits,

Or starting from scratch in a new field,

Your brain is ready to help you transform.

Yes, it takes time. Yes, it takes effort. But the science says it‚Äôs possible.

Here‚Äôs how you can tap into neuroplasticity:

Practice Consistently: Repetition strengthens those neural pathways.

Stay Curious: New challenges stimulate brain growth.

Embrace Setbacks: Each failure teaches your brain something new.

Surround Yourself with Growth: Environments and people matter.

Your brain is your partner in this journey. If it can adapt after strokes, injuries, and life-altering experiences, imagine what it can do for you today.

You have the power to change‚Äînot just your skills, but your entire mindset.

These are a few things that I've been learning when I am studying our human mind and psychology. Do you like such posts, you want me to share more?

Importance of comma -

Ruko, mat likho interested.

Ruko mat, likho interested.

Also an example of selective hearing :p

Setting Goals isn't the most important thing.

Working on that goal.‚úÖ
Planning the things you need to achieve that goal.‚úÖ
Giving yourself a deadline‚úÖ

and then being disciplined about it is important.

A goal without an action plan is a dream.

Write a goal on your wall and plan it. Give yourself time to achieve it and take active actions towards it.
